lesson.name: Lesson 5.6: Negative Exponents and Scientific Notation

page.title: 5.6.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will examine the meaning of negative exponents in the context of exponential growth and decay. Using data in a table, you will write equations and answer questions, some of which require working with negative values representing time. In one case, you will also produce a graph. As with many other activities in this unit, the mathematical work is grounded and interpreted in a context. These equations with negative exponents are frequently used in solving real-world problems where estimates are taken, including population sizes, financial calculations, and many other scientific measurements.

You will learn to convert numbers fluently between decimal form and scientific notation. This will allow you to easily perform operations on and represent large and small values in any context. Scientific notation is an extremely valuable tool for representing very large and small numbers that frequently occur as scientists take real-world measurements.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe the meaning of a negative exponent in equations that represent exponential growth and decay.
  • Write equations that represent exponential growth and decay to solve problems.
  • Graph an equation that represents exponential decay to solve a problem.
  • Convert numbers between decimal form and scientific notation.
  • Use scientific notation to solve problems arising from real-world situations.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 5.6.1: Checking Exponent Rules
  • 5.6.2: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Growth
    • 5.6.2: Self Check
  • 5.6.3: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Decay
    • 5.6.3: Self Check
  • 5.6.4: Using Scientific Notation
    • 5.6.4: Self Check
  • 5.6.5: Applying Scientific Notation
    • 5.6.5: Self Check
  • 5.6.6: Interpreting Negative Exponents and Scientific Notation

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 5.6.7: Practice
  • 5.6.8: Lesson Summary

page.title: 5.6.1: Checking Exponent Rules
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

How would you rewrite each of the following as an equivalent expression with a single exponent?


  1. \(2^4\cdot 2^0\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(2^4\)



  1. \(2^4\cdot 2^{-1}\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(2^3\)



  1. \(2^4\cdot 2^{-3}\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(2^1\)



  1. \(2^4\cdot 2^{-4}\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(2^0\)

page.title: 5.6.2: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Growth
page.contents:
Activity

A marine biologist estimates that a structure of coral has a volume of 1,200 cubic centimeters and that its volume doubles each year.


  1. Write an equation of the form \(y=a\cdot b^t\) representing the relationship, where \(t\) is time in years since the coral was measured and \(y\) is volume of coral in cubic centimeters. (You need to figure out what numbers \(a\) and \(b\) are in this situation.)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=1,200\cdot 2^t\)


  1. Find the volume of the coral when \(t\) is 5, 1, 0, –1, and –2. Note that when \(t = -1\), this represents one year before the marine biologist made the original estimate.

time (years)

5

1

0

–1

–2

volume of coral (cubic centimeters)

 

 

 

 

 

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

time (years)

5

1

0

–1

–2

volume of coral (cubic centimeters)

38,400

2,400

1,200

600

300


  1. What does it mean, in this situation, when \(t\) is –2?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

This represents the time 2 years before the scientist made the estimate of 1,200 cubic centimeters.


  1. In a certain year, the volume of the coral is 37.5 cubic centimeters. Which year is this? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(t\) is –5, or 5 years before the scientist made the estimate of 1,200 cubic centimeters.

page.title: 5.6.2: Self Check
page.contents: Using the equation \(p=10,000\cdot 2^d\), find the value of \(p\) when \(d = -2\).

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The expression \(p=10,000\cdot2^{-2}=2,500\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the value when \(d =1\). Evaluate the expression when \(d=-2\). \(p=10,000\cdot2^{-2}\). The answer is 2,500.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the value when \(d=-1\). Find the value when \(d=-2\). Evaluate the expression \(p=10,000\cdot2^{-2}\). The answer is 2,500.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the value when \(d=2\). Find the value when \(d=-2\). Evaluate the expression \(p=10,000\cdot2^{-2}\). The answer is 2,500.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.6.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Growth

Let’s look at a problem involving an exponential growth equation and negative exponents.

A forest fire has been burning for several days. The burned area, in acres, is given by the equation \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\), where \(d\) is the number of days since the area of the fire was first measured.

  1. Let’s complete the table.

    2. \(d\), days since first measurement

    \(y\), acres burned since fire started

    0

    		 a. _____

    –1

    		 b. _____

    –2

    		 c. _____

    –3

    		 d. _____

    –5

    		 e. _____

    a. _____
    Substitute 0 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^0\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 1\)
    \(y=4,800\)
    4,800

    b. _____
    Substitute –1 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^{-1}\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot\frac12\)
    \(y=2,400\)
    2,400

    c. _____
    Substitute –2 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^{-2}\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot\frac14\)
    \(y=1,200\)
    1,200

    d. _____
    Substitute –3 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^{-3}\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot\frac18\)
    \(y=600\)
    600

    e. _____
    Substitute –5 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^{-5}\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot\frac1{32}\)
    \(y=150\)
    150


    \(d\), days since first measurement

    \(y\), acres burned since fire started

    0

    4,800

    –1

    2,400

    –2

    1,200

    –3

    600

    –5

    150

  2. Look at the value of \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\) when \(d=-1\). What does it tell you about the area burned in the fire?

    3. It tells you that 1 day before the first measurement, 2,400 acres had burned.

  3. How much area had the fire burned a week before it measured 4,800 acres? Explain your reasoning.

    4. Substitute –7 for \(d\).

    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^d\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot 2^{-7}\)
    \(y=4,800\cdot\frac1{128}\)
    \(y=37.5\)

    37.5 acres had burned a week before the fire measured 4,800 acres. The solution is found by substituting –7 for \(d\) since that represents 7 days before the first measurement of 4,800 acres.

Try It: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Growth

The value of a home in 2015 was $400,000. Its value has doubled each decade.

  1. If \(v\) is the value of the home, in dollars, write an equation for \(v\) in terms of \(d\), the number of decades since 2015.
  2. What is \(v\) when \(d=-1\)? What does this value mean?
  3. What is \(v\) when \(d=-3\)? What does this value mean?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to solve this exponential growth problem using negative exponents:

  1. \(v=400,000\cdot 2^d\)

  2. Substitute –1 for \(d\).

    \(v=400,000\cdot 2^d\)
    \(v=400,000\cdot 2^{-1}\)
    \(v=400,000\cdot\frac12\)
    \(v=200,000\)

    So, \(v = 200,000\) when \(d=-1\); This means the home had a value of 200,000 in 2005, one decade before 2015.

  3. Substitute –3 for \(d\).

    \(v=400,000\cdot 2^d\)
    \(v=400,000\cdot 2^{-3}\)
    \(v=400,000\cdot\frac18\)
    \(v=50,000\)

    So, \(v = 50,000\) when \(d=-3\); This means the home had a value of 50,000 in 1985, three decades before 2015.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.6.3: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Decay
page.contents:
Activity

A person took some medicine but does not remember how much. Concerned that she took too much, she has a blood test every hour for several hours.

\(t\), time (hours)

\(m\), medicine (mg)

–3


–1

0

100

1

50

2

25


  1. Answer the following questions.

    a. Time \(t\) is measured in hours since the blood test, and amount of medicine in her body, \(m\), is measured in milligrams. What is the decay factor? That is, what is \(b\) in an equation of the form \(m=a\cdot b^t\)? What is \(a\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(b=\frac12\), \(a=100\)


    1. Find the amounts of medicine in the patient’s body when \(t\) is –1 and –3.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

When \(t\) is –1, \(m\) is 200.
When \(t\) is –3, \(m\) is 800.


  1. What do \(t=0\) and \(t=-3\) mean in this context?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(t=0\) means the time the doctor did the first blood test. \(t=-3\) means 3 hours before the doctor did the first test.


  1. The medicine was taken when \(t\) is –5. Assuming the person did not have any of the medication in her body beforehand, how much medicine did the patient take?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

3,200 mg. Each hour, this is cut in half. After being halved 5 times, it leaves 100 mg, the amount of medicine in the person’s body when \(t=0\).


  1. Plot the points whose coordinates are shown in the table. Make sure to draw and label tick marks on the axes.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:


  1. Based on your graph, when do you think the patient will have:
    1. 500 mg of medicine remaining in her body

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample response: Between 2 and 3 hours before the patient first had her blood tested


    1. No medicine remaining in her body

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample responses:

  • Sometime after 10 hours. The amount of medicine falls below 0.1 mg after about 10 hours and might be too small to be detectable after that point.
  • Eventually, all of the medicine will be out of the patient’s body (but the mathematical model for the amount of medicine does not reach 0).

Extending Your Thinking


Without evaluating them, describe each of the following quantities as close to 0, close to 1, or much larger than 1.

  1. \(\frac1{1-2^{-10}}\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • close to 1


  1. \(\frac{2^{10}}{2^{10}+1}\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • close to 1


  1. \(\frac{2^{-10}}{2^{10}+1}\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • close to 0


  1. \(\frac{1-2^{-10}}{2^{10}}\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • close to 0


  1. \(\frac{1+2^{10}}{2^{-10}}\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • much larger than 1

page.title: 5.6.3: Self Check
page.contents:
A census of hemlock trees is taken in a national park. The rangers have found that only \(\frac45\) of the population has survived each year. The data are shown in the table. Find the number of hemlocks that were in the park 2 years before the census was taken.


\(y\), years since census

\(h\), number of hemlocks

–2

  

0

64,000

1

51,200

3

32,768

answer.response:
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the solution for 4 years before the census was taken. The equation to represent this situation is

\(h=64,000\cdot\left(\frac45\right)^y\). The solution is found by substituting –2 for \(y\). The answer is 100,000.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the solution for 3 years before the census was taken. The equation to represent this situation is

\(h=64,000\cdot\left(\frac45\right)^y\). The solution is found by substituting –2 for \(y\). The answer is 100,000.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the solution for 1 year before the census was taken. Find the solution for 2 years before the census was taken. The equation to represent this situation is

\(h=64,000\cdot\left(\frac45\right)^y\). The solution is found by substituting –2 for \(y\). The answer is 100,000.
That’s correct! Check yourself: The equation to represent this situation is \(h=64,000\cdot\left(\frac45\right)^y\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.6.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Decay

Let’s look at a problem involving an exponential decay equation and negative exponents.

A scientist records the population of a bacterial population in a petri dish. The data are shown in the table.


\(d\), days since first test

\(b\), number of bacteria

–3

  

–1

  

0

40,000

1

20,000

3

5,000

The number of days \(d\) since the first test corresponds with the number of bacteria, \(b\), estimated to be alive in the petri dish.

  1. What is the decay factor? That is, what is \(f\) in an equation of the form \(b=n\cdot f^d\)? What is the starting population, \(n\), on the first day of testing?

    Since the number of bacteria found on day 0 is 40,000, then \(n = 40,000\). Since after each day, the number of bacteria is cut in half, then the decay factor, \(f\), is \(\frac12\).

    The equation to represent this situation is \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^d\).

  2. What do \(d=-1\) and \(d=-3\) mean in this context?

    \(d=0\) means the day the first test is taken. \(d=-1\) means 1 day before the scientist did the first test. \(d=-3\) means 3 days before the scientist did the first test.

  3. How many bacteria were present 1 day before the first test?

    Substitute –1 for \(d\) in the equation \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^d\).

    \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^d\)
    \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^{-1}\)
    \(b=40,000\cdot 2\)
    \(b=80,000\)

    There were 80,000 bacteria in the petri dish 1 day before the test.

  4. Assume the peak of the bacterial population was 3 days before the first test. How many bacteria were present at the peak of the population?

    Substitute –3 for \(d\) in the equation \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^d\).

    \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^d\)
    \(b=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^{-3}\)
    \(b=40,000\cdot 8\)
    \(b=320,000\)

    There were 320,000 bacteria in the petri dish 3 days before the test at the peak of the population.

Try It: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Decay

An investor has tracked the value of a particular investment since 2016 that has depreciated over time. The data are shown in the table.


\(y\), years since 2016

\(v\), value of investment ($)

–2

  

–1

  

0

36,000

1

12,000

2

4,000

  1. What is the equation that represents this situation?
  1. What do \(y=-1\) and \(y=-2\) mean in this context?
  1. If the value of the investment was at its highest in 2014, what was the maximum value of the investment?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to solve this exponential growth problem using negative exponents:

  1. The equation that represents this situation is \(v=36,000\cdot\left(\frac13\right)^y\). The value of the investment in year 0 is $36,000, and the decay factor is \(\frac13\).
  1. \(y=-1\) means 1 year before 2016, which is 2015. \(y=-2\) means 2 years before 2016, which is 2014.
  1. The maximum value of the investment was $324,000.

    \(v=36,000\cdot\left(\frac13\right)^y\)
    \(v=36,000\cdot\left(\frac13\right)^{-2}\)
    \(v=36,000\cdot 9\)
    \(v=324,000\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.6.4: Using Scientific Notation
page.contents:
Activity

  1. How would you write each of the following numbers in scientific notation?

Decimal Form

Scientific Notation

0.00000654

  

0.0000947

  

683,000

  

0.022

  

5,200

  

0.000352

  

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:


Decimal Form

Scientific Notation

0.00000654

\(6.54\times10^{-6}\)

0.0000947

\(9.47\times10^{-5}\)

683,000

\(6.83\times10^5\)

0.022

\(2.2\times10^{-2}\)

5,200

\(5.2\times10^3\)

0.000352

\(3.52\times10^{-4}\)

  1. How would you write each of the following scientific notation values in decimal form?

Scientific Notation

Decimal Form

\(7.26\times10^{-4}\)

  

\(3.32\times10^{-2}\)

   

\(9.4\times10^6\)

  

\(8.87\times10^{-1}\)

  

\(6.395\times10^4\)

  

\(4.0\times10^{-3}\)

  

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:


Scientific Notation

Decimal Form

\(7.26\times10^{-4}\)

0.000726

\(3.32\times10^{-2}\)

0.0332

\(9.4\times10^6\)

9,400,000

\(8.87\times10^{-1}\)

0.887

\(6.395\times10^4\)

63,950

\(4.0\times10^{-3}\)

0.004

Video: Converting between Scientific Notation and Decimal Form

Watch the following video to learn more about rewriting scientific notation in decimal form and decimal form in scientific notation.

page.title: 5.6.4: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following equations is true?

answer.response:
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiplying by \(10^3\) means multiplying by 1000.

\(7.64\times 1000 = 7,640\). The answer is \(8.5\times 10^{-4} = 0.00085\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiplying by \(10^5\) means multiplying by 100,000. \(9.11\times 100,000 = 911,000\). The answer is \(8.5\times 10^{-4} = 0.00085\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiplying by \(10^{-4}\) means dividing by 10,000. The values are equivalent.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiplying by \(10^{-5}\) means dividing by 100,000. \(2.36\times 10^{-5} = 0.0000236\). The answer is \(8.5\times 10^{-4} = 0.00085\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.6.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Using Scientific Notation

Working with very large or very small numbers can be awkward. Since our number system is base ten, we can use powers of ten to rewrite very large or very small numbers to make them easier to work with. Consider the numbers 4,000 and 0.004.

Using place value, we can rewrite the numbers 4,000 and 0.004. We know that 4,000 means \(4\times 1,000\) and 0.004 means \(4\times\frac1{1000}\).

If we write the 1,000 as a power of ten in exponential form, we can rewrite these numbers in this way:


4,000

\(4\times 1,000\)

\(4\times 10^3\)


0.004

\(4\times\frac1{1000}\)

\(4\times\frac1{10^3}\)

\(4\times 10^{-3}\)

When a number is written as a product of two numbers, where the first factor is a number greater than or equal to 1 but less than 10, and the second factor is a power of 10 written in exponential form, it is said to be in scientific notation.


A number is expressed in scientific notation when it is of what form?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(a\times 10^n\), where \(1 \leq│a│< 10\) and \(n\) is an integer.


It is customary in scientific notation to use × as the multiplication sign, even though we avoid using this sign elsewhere in algebra.


To convert a decimal to scientific notation:

Step 1. Move the decimal point so that the first factor is greater than or equal to 1 but less than 10.

Step 2. Count the number of decimal places, \(n\), that the decimal point was moved.

Step 3. Write the number as a product with a power of 10. If the original number is

  • greater than 1, the power of 10 will be \(10^n\).
  • between 0 and 1, the power of 10 will be \(10^{−n}\).

Step 4. Check.


Example: Write in scientific notation:

  1. 37,000
    Solution:
  2. 0.0052
    Solution:
To convert scientific notation to decimal form:

Step 1. Determine the exponent, \(n\), on the factor of 10.

Step 2. Move the decimal \(n\) places, adding zeros if needed.

  • If the exponent is positive, move the decimal point \(n\) places to the right.
  • If the exponent is negative, move the decimal point \(n\) places to the left.

Step 3. Check.

Example: Write in decimal form:

  1. \(6.2 \times 10^3\)
    Solution:

  2. \(-8.9\times10^{-2}\)
    Solution:

Try It: Using Scientific Notation

Write in scientific notation.

  1. 65,000,000
  2. 0.00034

Write in decimal form.

  1. \(5.3 \times10^5 \)
  2. \(4.25 \times10^{-3}\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to write the numbers:

  1. \( 6.5 \times10^7 \)
  2. \( 3.4\times10^{-4} \)
  3. 530,000
  4. 0.00425

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.6.5: Applying Scientific Notation
page.contents:
Activity

  1. A biologist receives bird population estimates for different parks. The estimates are shown in the table. Work with your partner to arrange these estimates in order from least to greatest.

Park

Bird Population

Shady Elm

\(7.5\times10^3\)

Westcott Park

105,000

Brighton Park

\(4.5\times10^2\)

Red Elk

22,300

Bear Park

\(1.1\times10^5\)

Daniels Park

3,300

Blue Spruce

\(1.25\times10^4\)

Yellow Jay Park

\(2.25\times10^4\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • Brighton Park, \(4.5\times10^2\)
  • Daniels Park, 3,300
  • Shady Elm, \(7.5\times10^3\)
  • Blue Spruce, \(1.25\times10^4\)
  • Red Elk, 22,300
  • Yellow Jay Park, \(2.25\times10^4\)
  • Westcott Park, 105,000
  • Bear Park, \(1.1\times10^5\)


  1. Enrico weighs the small objects shown for a science project. Work with your partner to arrange these weights in order from heaviest to lightest.

Object

Weight (lb)

grain of sand

\(1.4\times10^{-4}\)

grain of pollen

0.00001014

one drop of water

0.00011

a feather

\(1.8\times10^{-5}\)

one kernel of corn

\(1.1\times10^{-3}\)

house fly

\(3.08\times10^{-5}\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • one kernel of corn, \(1.1\times10^{-3}\)
  • grain of sand, \(1.4\times10^{-4}\)
  • one drop of water, 0.00011
  • house fly, \(3.08\times10^{-5}\)
  • a feather, \(1.8\times10^{-5}\)
  • grain of pollen, 0.00001014



  1. What do you notice when comparing numbers in scientific notation with different negative exponents?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

If both exponents are negative, then the number with the smaller absolute value exponent is the larger number. For example, the number with the exponent \(–3\) is larger than the number with the exponent \(–4\).

page.title: 5.6.5: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the numbers shown is the greatest?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Compare the numbers in the same form. 0.0065 is equivalent to \(6.5\times10^{-3}\). This is not the greatest number. The answer is \(7.2\times10^{-3}\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The number \(7.2\times10^{-3}\) is the largest value. It is equivalent to 0.0072.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Compare the numbers in the same form. 0.00084 is equivalent to \(8.4\times10^{-4}\). \(10^{-4}\) is less than \(10^{-3}\). The answer is \(7.2\times10^{-3}\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: \(10^{-5}\) is less than \(10^{-4}\). \(9.6\times10^{-5}\) is equivalent to 0.000096. The answer is \(7.2\times10^{-3}\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.6.5: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Applying Scientific Notation

Let’s look at how to solve a real-world problem involving scientific notation.

The specimens below are measured lengths of different tiny animals. Arrange them in order from shortest to longest.


Specimen

Length (m)

A

\(7.0\times10^{-3}\)

B

0.0000847

C

0.00022

D

\(1.8\times10^{-4}\)

E

\(8.92\times10^{-3}\)

F

\(6.03\times10^{-2}\)

To solve this problem, we can convert all of the measurements to decimal form or standard form.

Let’s convert all measurements to decimal form from scientific notation.


Specimen

Length (m)

A

\(7.0\times10^{-3} = 0.007\)

B

0.0000847

C

0.00022

D

\(1.8\times10^{-4} = 0.00018\)

E

\(8.92\times10^{-3} = 0.00892\)

F

\(6.03\times10^{-2} = 0.0603\)

We can now arrange the decimal values in order from shortest to longest:

B, D, C, A, E, F

Let’s convert each length into scientific notation and check our answer.


Specimen

Length (m)

A

\(7.0\times10^{-3}\)

B

\(0.0000847 = 8.47\times 10^{-5}\)

C

\(0.00022 = 2.2 \times 10^{-4}\)

D

\(1.8\times10^{-4}\)

E

\(8.92\times10^{-3}\)

F

\(6.03\times10^{-2}\)

The negative exponent with the largest absolute value represents the smallest number, so B is the shortest length.

The negative exponent with the smallest absolute value represents the largest number, so F is the longest length.

When the exponents are equal, compare the decimal part of the number.

The order B, D, C, A, E, F is correct from shortest to longest length.

Try It: Applying Scientific Notation

The measurements in the table are sample wavelengths for the given types of waves. Arrange them in order from shortest to longest.


Color

Wavelength (m)

red light

\(7.0\times10^{-7}\)

blue light

0.00000045

infrared light

\(5.0\times10^{-4}\)

ultraviolet light

\(2.0\times10^{-9}\)

microwaves

\(1.5\times10^{-1}\)

radio waves

2.1

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to arrange the measurements from shortest to longest:

Let’s convert the values for blue light and radio waves into scientific notation to compare all the values.

blue light = \(0.00000045 = 4.5\times 10^{-7}\)

radio waves = \(2.1 = 2.1\times 10^0\)

So, from shortest to longest the wavelengths are:

ultraviolet light, \(2.0\times10^{-9}\)
blue light, \(4.5\times10^{-7}\)
red light, \(7.0\times10^{-7}\)
infrared light, \(5.0\times10^{-4}\)
microwaves, \(1.5\times10^{-1}\)
radio waves, \(2.1\times10^0\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.6.6: Interpreting Negative Exponents and Scientific Notation
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The equation \(p=5,000\cdot2^t\) represents the population of an invasive fish species in a large lake, \(t\) years since 2005, when the fish population in the lake was first surveyed.


  1. What was the population in 2005?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

5,000, because \(5,000\cdot 2^0=5,000\).



  1. What is this value of the population in 2005 in scientific notation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(5.0\times 10^3\)



  1. For this model, what does it mean when \(t\) is –2?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It means 2 years before 2005, which is 2003.



  1. For \( t=-2\), is the fish population more or less than 1,000? How do you know?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

More than 1,000. For \(t=-2\), \(5,000\cdot 2^{-2}=1,250\).



  1. Write the value of the fish population when \(t=-2\) in scientific notation.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(1.25\times 10^3 \)

page.title: 5.6.7: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Use the following passage to answer questions 1–3.

In a newly formed swamp, it is estimated that there are 500 mosquitoes. The population is estimated to double each day.

  1. Let \(m\) represent the total population of mosquitoes and \(d\) represent the number of days that have passed since the first estimate. What is the equation that represents the growth of the mosquito population?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.6.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(m=500\cdot 2^d\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What does \(d=-2\) represent in this context?

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 5.6.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 2 days before the first estimate was taken. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the estimated number of mosquitoes that were in the new swamp 1 day before the estimate was taken?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.6.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 250. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following passage to answer questions 4–6.

A desert pond is slowly drying up. The average volume of the pond is shown in the table. The first year it was measured, the average volume was determined to be 40,000 liters.


\(y\), years

\(v\), volume (liters)

–4

  

–2

  

0

40,000

1

20,000

3

5,000

  1. Which equation represents the pond’s water loss?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(v=40,000\cdot\left(\frac12\right)^y\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What does \(y=-2\) represent in this context?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the time 2 years before the first time the volume was measured. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What was the average volume of the pond 4 years before the first time the volume was measured?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.6.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 640,000 liters. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to 6,350,000 in scientific notation?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(6.35\times 10^6\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to 0.00032 in scientific notation?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(3.2\times 10^{-4}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to \(7.24\times 10^3\) in decimal form?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 7,240. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following is equivalent to \(5.47\times 10^{-5}\) in decimal form?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 0.0000547. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following correctly orders these values from greatest to least?

    Value R

    0.00161

    Value S

    \(6.35\times 10^{-3}\)

    Value T

    0.000541

    Value U

    \(7.23\times 10^{-4}\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.6.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Value S, Value R, Value U, Value T. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 5.6.8: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Describe the meaning of a negative exponent in equations that represent exponential growth and decay.
  • Write equations that represent exponential growth and decay to solve problems.
  • Graph an equation that represents exponential decay to solve a problem.
  • Convert numbers between decimal form and scientific notation.
  • Use scientific notation to solve problems arising from real-world situations.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 5.6.1: Checking Exponent Rules
    • In this activity, you reviewed performing operations with exponents, including negative exponents. You used the Product Property of Exponents to simplify the expressions.
  • 5.6.2: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Growth
    • In this activity, you wrote an equation of exponential growth to represent a real-life situation. You interpreted the meaning of negative exponents in this equation. You used negative exponents in exponential growth equations to solve real-world problems.
  • 5.6.2: Self Check
  • 5.6.3: Interpreting Negative Exponents in Exponential Decay
    • In this activity, you wrote an equation of exponential decay to represent a real-life situation. You also created a graph to represent the situation. You interpreted the meaning of negative exponents in this equation. You used negative exponents in exponential decay equations to solve real-world problems.
  • 5.6.3: Self Check
  • 5.6.4: Applying Scientific Notation
    • In this activity, you converted values between decimal form and scientific notation.
  • 5.6.4: Self Check
  • 5.6.5: Applying Scientific Notation
    • In this activity, you used what you know about scientific notation to solve real-world problems.
  • 5.6.5: Self Check
  • 5.6.6: Interpreting Negative Exponents and Scientific Notation
    • In this activity, you interpreted negative exponents in a scenario about the population of fish. Then you changed between the standard from and the scientific notation at specific points.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 5.6.7: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
